metaTitle: USA Salary Calculator | Federal & State Taxes, Take-Home Pay 2025 | SalaryWise.io
metaDescription: Calculate your take-home pay in the United States with 2025 federal tax brackets, state income taxes, Social Security, Medicare, and deductions. Free USA salary calculator.
intro: Calculate your exact take-home pay in the United States with our comprehensive 2024 tax calculator. Includes federal income tax brackets, state taxes for all 50 states, Social Security, Medicare, standard deductions, and dependent credits. Perfect for tax planning, salary negotiations, and understanding your paycheck.

ui.noResultsText: Enter your salary details to calculate take-home pay

howItWorks: This USA salary calculator uses 2025 federal tax brackets and state income tax rates. We calculate your taxable income after deductions, apply progressive tax rates, include FICA taxes (Social Security + Medicare), and provide monthly/biweekly breakdowns. All calculations follow IRS guidelines and include the latest tax law updates.
whenToUse: Evaluating job offers in different states
Planning for state tax differences when moving
Budgeting with accurate take-home pay figures

example.scenario: A single software engineer earns $85,000 annually in California with 2 dependents and $6,000 retirement contributions.
example.results: Federal tax: $10,456 | State tax: $11,305 | FICA: $6,510 | Total tax: $28,271 | Net take-home: $56,729 | Monthly: $4,727

faqs.question: Are these calculations accurate for 2025?
faqs.answer: Yes, we use official 2025 federal tax brackets, state tax rates, and FICA limits from the IRS and state revenue departments.

faqs.question: Does this include all state taxes?
faqs.answer: Yes, we include income taxes for all 50 states plus DC. Note that some states have additional local taxes not included here.

faqs.question: What's the difference between marginal and effective tax rates?
faqs.answer: Effective tax rate is your total tax divided by income. Marginal tax rate is the tax rate on your next dollar of income.

faqs.question: Can I include itemized deductions?
faqs.answer: Yes, use the 'Additional Deductions' field for itemized deductions beyond the standard deduction.

faqs.question: Are retirement contributions tax-deductible?
faqs.answer: Yes, pre-tax retirement contributions (401k, IRA) reduce your taxable income and are included in the calculations.

tips: Maximize retirement contributions to reduce taxable income
Consider state tax differences when choosing where to live
Use the standard deduction unless you have significant itemized deductions
Keep good records for estimated quarterly tax payments
Review W-4 withholdings annually to avoid large refunds or bills
disclaimer: SalaryWise provides estimated take-home pay based on publicly available tax structures. Results are for guidance only.

mainEntity.name: Are these US tax calculations accurate for 2025?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, we use official 2025 federal tax brackets and all current state tax rates from the IRS and state revenue departments.

mainEntity.name: Does this include taxes for all 50 states?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, we include income taxes for all 50 US states plus Washington DC. States with no income tax (Texas, Florida, Nevada, etc.) show $0 state tax.

mainEntity.name: What's the difference between marginal and effective tax rates?

acceptedAnswer.text: Effective tax rate is your total tax divided by income. Marginal tax rate is the tax rate on your next dollar of income (the highest bracket you're in).
Yes, pre-tax retirement contributions (401k, IRA, etc.) reduce your taxable income and are calculated automatically.

mainEntity.name: How often should I update my W-4?

acceptedAnswer.text: Review your W-4 annually, especially after major life changes like marriage, having children, or significant salary changes.
